I do think we all need to seriously consider these things. There's a bunch of people (myself included) anxious for the atmosphere of in-person meetings. But who is going to be left behind again? Gotta beware of rushing to "return to normalcy" and leaving behind equity

Networking plays a huge role at conferences, being introduced to others in the field by your PI etc, and the loss of that in virtual conferences is felt by younger trainees. Obvs that's an equity problem to begin with, ppl that couldn't attend also didn't get that "face time"

I'm also still waiting for a good format for virtual poster sessions. As a trainee, the amount of interaction at posters that I got at in-person meetings  is much more than virtual ones--and at the virtual ones, many of the people attending were those I met in person before

I do wonder how much of this would hold true for the virtual conferences of 2021/2022--in my sphere, people were much more enthusiastic about virtual conferences on 2020, and now it feels like everyone is so burnt out on zoom that engagement is way down https://t.co/4XQc4dVOQ0
